On the other hand, Magua is driven by a desire for revenge and is portrayed as a cowardly and treacherous character. His paralysis by terror or shame could be due to Uncas's unwavering courage and the fear of the consequences if he fails to execute his plan of vengeance. Uncas is still present, but he has been moved from where Duncan left him and is now under the watchful eyes of a young Huron warrior and an armed sentry by the door. David, however, is not in the lodge. Duncan sees that the Hurons have carried the senseless remains of the executed person into the woods, and he wanders around the village looking for any trace of Alice, motivated by both his concern for her and his interest in Uncas's fate. After searching the entire village without success, he returns to the council lodge, intending to find and question David to put an end to his doubts.

Despite the intimidation and harsh treatment, Uncas maintained his courage and dignity throughout the ordeal.

edge.source: The white-headed savage who claimed that the person called his son was not his real son is the father of the recant Indian. He stood out among the warriors in the lodge because he was becoming an object of general attention, and when he arose, he lifted his voice in the general silence, making a speech that revealed his true feelings about his son and the situation. He was distinct from the other warriors as he was an older man, and his facial expressions and body language showed his anguish, contradicting his boastful language. His white hair also made him stand out, as it was not common among the Hurons.

The speaker, who was the father of the recreant young Indian, looked round and about him, as if seeking commendation of his stoicism in the eyes of his auditors. But the stern customs of his people had made too severe an exaction of the feeble old man. The expression of his eye contradicted his figurative and boastful language, while every muscle in his wrinkled visage was working with anguish. Standing a single minute to enjoy his bitter triumph, he turned away, as if sickening at the gaze of men, and veiling his face in his blanket, he walked from the lodge with the noiseless step of an Indian, seeking, in the privacy of his own abode, the sympathy of one like himself, aged, forlorn, and childless.
